data.text: Minerals
Minerals are of two types – metallic and non-metallic.
Pakistan has vast resources of non-metallic minerals.
Gypsum, barite, rock salt, magnesite, soapstone, fluorite, sulphur, gemstones, marble, clays and limestone are the major non-metallic minerals found in Pakistan.
Gypsum is found in the Salt Range. It is mostly mined at Khewra, Dandot, and Daud Khel.
Barite is mainly used in the oil industry.
Rock salt is mined in the Salt Range. Its major use is in the food industry.
Magnesite is mined at Spin Kan in Balochistan.
It is used in the manufacture of cement, paper, and rayon.
Soapstone is found in Zhob, Safed Koh, and Sherwan. It is used in making soap, ceramics, and face powder.
Fluorite is found in Koh-i-Maran and Koh-i-Dilband.
Sulphur is found in Koh-i-Sultan and Sanni. It is used as a raw material for making sulphuric acid.
Limestone is found mainly in the Salt Range and the Margalla Hills.
In Pakistan, chromite is the only metallic mineral mined on a large scale.
Chromite is mined at Muslim Bagh near Quetta.
Small quantities of copper, iron, manganese, antimony, and bauxite are also mined in Pakistan.
Power Resources
Pakistan uses much less energy than many countries, but it does not produce enough energy to meet its needs.
The energy used in Pakistan comes from oil, gas, water, and coal.
Petroleum is made from oil which is found deep below the surface of the Earth.
The Oil and Gas Development Corporation was set up in Pakistan in 1961.
The oilfields of Pakistan are located in the Potohar Plateau and Lower Sindh.
The Attock refinery at Morgah in Rawalpindi is the oldest refinery in Pakistan.
Pakistan has large deposits of natural gas.
The largest gas field in Pakistan is at Sui and the second largest is at Marri.
Natural gas is Pakistan's second most important source of energy after water.
Pakistan produces electricity through various hydroelectric, thermal, and nuclear power plants.
Hydroelectricity is produced by constructing a dam across a fast-flowing river.
Tarbela, Mangla, and Warsak dams are three major hydroelectricity projects of Pakistan.
Most of the hydel plants of Pakistan are located in upper Punjab and the NWFP.
Most of the electricity in Pakistan is produced by thermal power plants.
Thermal power is generated from heat produced by burning oil, gas, or coal.
Karachi is the largest centre of thermal electricity in Pakistan.
Pakistan has two nuclear power plants—one at Karachi and the other at Chashma.
Nuclear Power Plants
Nuclear power plants are very expensive to build.
The major coal mining is done in the Sor Range near Quetta in Pakistan.
Pakistan has large coal reserves which have not yet been exploited.
Solar energy is also used in Pakistan on a very small scale.
Development of solar energy is still at an experimental stage.
Wind energy is another source of energy that can be developed in coastal areas and plains.
The development of wind power is still in its early stages in Pakistan.
We should value our natural resources and use them carefully.
Overexploitation of natural resources may lead to their exhaustion one day.
